Relationship of Radio and TV in a University
Ohio State University has applied for a television license* Much planning
has preceded its application* Much more planning will be needed before OSU can
establish and put a television station into operation, assuming a television license
is issued. It is to be expected that responsible OSU officials would appreciate
receiving information which would help them in the establishment and operation of
a TV station.
WE at WOSU assume that our primary responsibility Is to extend the ser¬
vices of the university to adult Ohio listeners. Should this also be the chief
concern of the television statiori^r should the TV outlet be used primarily as a
training laboratory for students aspiring to find work in television? Or should
it be used for both purposes? Another important question is should radio and
television be combined and operated under one management thus using some of the
same equipment and personnel in both broadcasting media?
Until OSU officials feel they have the answers to these and other ques¬
tions, they will find it difficult to make adequate decisions on the kind of build¬
ing needed, amount and kind of equipment to order, and qualifications of televison
personnelo One means of helping these OSU officials to acquire some of the neces-
saiy information would be for the NAEB to make available to them descriptions of
existing television operations such as at Iowa State College and Michigan State
Collegeo
Job Evaluation
Regardless of whether or not Ohio State University obtains a television
station, it can continue to improve its radio station© One way for inprovement
is for the station staff to make an evaluation of the work which each member does*
This self-evaluation could be more effectively accomplished if staff members had
job descriptions of other university radio stations* Would it be possible for NAEB
to devise a self-evaluation farm tfo.ich radio workers could use in describing their
jobs and rating them? Secondly, could NAEB circulate these descriptions among the
interested stations?
Group and Leadership Training
Commercial firms, industries, labor unions, educationo©©.©all have this
one problem in common, that of group and leadership training. Staff members of
an educational radio station must work together as a team© Sometimes their team¬
work suffers from inadequate leadership; other times from lack of knowledge among
staff members to work as members of a group© Could the NAEB provide regional
training centers where station personnel, ranging from station manager to the
student working part time as announcer, could go to loam more about how to play
their roles as group members and group leaders? Workers in the fields of speech
and adult education should be able to assist in organizing such regional training
centers.
